item.title: To Prepare For Mars Settlement, Simulated Missions Explore Utah's Desert
item.description: July 6, 2017 - NASA plans to send people to the Red Planet in the 2030s. In the meantime, a remote location in southern Utah serves as a non-NASA training ground for the Mars-minded.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - NASA plans to send people to the Red Planet in the 2030s. In the meantime, a remote location in southern Utah serves as a non-NASA training ground for the Mars-minded. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/06/522060920/to-prepare-for-mars-settlement-simulated-missions-explore-utahs-desert

item.title: Montana Earthquake Is Felt For Hundreds Of Miles Early Thursday
item.description: July 6, 2017 - The earthquake was the strongest to hit western Montana in years; it was followed by at least 10 measurable temblors with magnitudes of up to 4.9.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - The earthquake was the strongest to hit western Montana in years; it was followed by at least 10 measurable temblors with magnitudes of up to 4.9. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/06/535741701/montana-earthquake-is-felt-for-hundreds-of-miles-early-thursday

item.title: Physics For Toddlers
item.description: July 6, 2017 - There's a dearth of books about science and math for young children. As part of our series on kids' media we take a look at some books that introduce rocket science and physics to toddlers and babies.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - There's a dearth of books about science and math for young children. As part of our series on kids' media we take a look at some books that introduce rocket science and physics to toddlers and babies. http://www.npr.org/sections/ed/2017/07/06/535732200/physics-for-toddlers

item.title: Damage From Wayward Weedkiller Keeps Growing
item.description: July 6, 2017 - As many as 2 million acres of soybeans may have been harmed by a popular weedkiller drifting into neighboring fields. Arkansas' proposed ban on the herbicide, dicamba, is awaiting final approval.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 6, 2017 - As many as 2 million acres of soybeans may have been harmed by a popular weedkiller drifting into neighboring fields. Arkansas' proposed ban on the herbicide, dicamba, is awaiting final approval. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/07/06/535669282/damage-from-wayward-weedkiller-keeps-growing

item.title: Top Performers Risk Being Undermined By Peers, Studies Show
item.description: July 5, 2017 - Studies highlighted in Scientific American indicate a propensity for less-well-performing employees to take aim at the efforts of their star coworkers.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 5, 2017 - Studies highlighted in Scientific American indicate a propensity for less-well-performing employees to take aim at the efforts of their star coworkers. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/05/535648497/top-performers-risk-being-undermined-by-peers-studies-shows

item.title: Aztec 'Tower Of Skulls' Reveals Women, Children Were Sacrificed
item.description: July 5, 2017 - Some 650 skulls unearthed in Mexico City are believed to be the legendary Huey Tzompantli, a site for victims of human sacrifice first mentioned by Spanish conquistadors.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 5, 2017 - Some 650 skulls unearthed in Mexico City are believed to be the legendary Huey Tzompantli, a site for victims of human sacrifice first mentioned by Spanish conquistadors. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/05/535613480/aztec-tower-of-skulls-reveals-women-children-were-sacrificed

item.title: Appeals Court Says EPA Can't Keep Delaying Obama-Era Methane Rules
item.description: July 4, 2017 - The U.S. Court of Appeals for D.C. notes the EPA can choose to rewrite a rule designed to prevent leaks from natural gas facilities. But it can't just put it off for two years, the judges decided.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 4, 2017 - The U.S. Court of Appeals for D.C. notes the EPA can choose to rewrite a rule designed to prevent leaks from natural gas facilities. But it can't just put it off for two years, the judges decided. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/04/535509920/appeals-court-says-epa-cant-keep-delaying-obama-era-methane-rules

item.title: Scientists Are Not So Hot At Predicting Which Cancer Studies Will Succeed
item.description: July 4, 2017 - A scientist tested his peers' ability to pick which cancer experiments would pan out. They failed more often than not, which doesn't say much for intuition or efficiency in the scientific process.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 4, 2017 - A scientist tested his peers' ability to pick which cancer experiments would pan out. They failed more often than not, which doesn't say much for intuition or efficiency in the scientific process. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/07/04/535412346/scientists-are-not-so-hot-at-predicting-which-cancer-studies-will-succeed

item.title: United By The Sun: A Solar Event For All Americans To Share
item.description:
July 4, 2017 - Skywatchers and astrophysicists are already gearing up for next month's "Great American Solar Eclipse."
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-07-04/total-eclipse
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 4, 2017 - Skywatchers and astrophysicists are already gearing up for next month's "Great American Solar Eclipse." http://the1a.org/shows/2017-07-04/total-eclipse

item.title: In Russia's Siberian Silicon Valley, Business Is Good But Risks Can Be High
item.description: July 4, 2017 - The Soviet Union built research institutes in Siberia as innovation centers during the Cold War. Since then, there's been a brain drain. Tech innovators remain, but some have faced legal challenges.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 4, 2017 - The Soviet Union built research institutes in Siberia as innovation centers during the Cold War. Since then, there's been a brain drain. Tech innovators remain, but some have faced legal challenges. http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/07/04/535401305/in-russias-siberian-silicon-valley-business-is-good-but-risks-can-be-high

item.title: Research Shows Birth Order Really Does Matter
item.description: July 4, 2017 - Compared to older siblings, second-born boys are more likely to go to prison, get suspended in school and enter juvenile delinquency. Why? Parents of first-borns are more invested in their upbringing.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 4, 2017 - Compared to older siblings, second-born boys are more likely to go to prison, get suspended in school and enter juvenile delinquency. Why? Parents of first-borns are more invested in their upbringing. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/04/535470953/research-shows-birth-order-really-does-matter

item.title: Natural Disasters May Widen Income Gap, Report Says
item.description: July 3, 2017 - Scientific American concludes that disasters correlate to a 1-percentage-point increase in poverty in the affected areas. It also finds that the rich leave disaster-prone areas but the poor can't.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 3, 2017 - Scientific American concludes that disasters correlate to a 1-percentage-point increase in poverty in the affected areas. It also finds that the rich leave disaster-prone areas but the poor can't. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/03/535406893/natural-disasters-may-widen-income-gap-report-says

item.title: Biologists Divided Over How To Save Endangered Pangolin
item.description: July 3, 2017 - The pangolin is a tiny snake-like creature. It's in great demand for its meat and scales, and it is in danger of extinction. Biologists can't agree on whether zoos should play a role in saving it.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 3, 2017 - The pangolin is a tiny snake-like creature. It's in great demand for its meat and scales, and it is in danger of extinction. Biologists can't agree on whether zoos should play a role in saving it. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/03/535408634/biologists-divided-over-how-to-save-endangered-pangolin

item.title: Another July 4th Anniversary: Pathfinder's Landing On Mars
item.description:
July 3, 2017 - In 1997, the spacecraft's mission paved the way for the more sophisticated rovers operating on the Red Planet today.
- http://www.npr.org/2017/07/03/535372087/another-july-4th-anniversary-pathfinders-landing-on-mars
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 3, 2017 - In 1997, the spacecraft's mission paved the way for the more sophisticated rovers operating on the Red Planet today. http://www.npr.org/2017/07/03/535372087/another-july-4th-anniversary-pathfinders-landing-on-mars

item.title: How Frogs Benefited From The Dinosaurs' Extinction
item.description: July 3, 2017 - Frogs are "master survivors," able to take advantage of the ecological vacuum left behind by extinct animals. Scientists say 9 in 10 frog species descended from three surviving frog lineages.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: July 3, 2017 - Frogs are "master survivors," able to take advantage of the ecological vacuum left behind by extinct animals. Scientists say 9 in 10 frog species descended from three surviving frog lineages. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/07/03/535383841/how-frogs-benefited-from-the-dinosaurs-extinction
